questions.question: An individual taxpayer has $15,000 of net capital losses for the year. How much can be deducted against ordinary income?
questions.explanation: Individual taxpayers can deduct up to $3,000 ($1,500 MFS) of net capital losses against ordinary income annually. The remaining $12,000 carries forward indefinitely until used.
questions.tip: Capital loss deduction: $3,000 max against ordinary income. Unlimited carryforward.

questions.question: A newly formed single-member LLC does not file Form 8832. For federal tax purposes, it is treated as:

options.B: A partnership

questions.explanation: A single-member LLC defaults to disregarded entity status, meaning its income and expenses are reported on the owner's return (Schedule C for individual owners). No separate entity return is required.
questions.tip: Single-member LLC default: Disregarded entity. Reports on owner's Schedule C (individual) or consolidated (corp owner).

questions.question: What is the maximum employee elective deferral to a 401(k) plan for 2024 for a taxpayer under age 50?
questions.explanation: The 2024 employee 401(k) deferral limit is $23,000 (under age 50). Those 50+ can contribute an additional $7,500 catch-up, for a total of $30,500.
questions.tip: 2024 401(k): $23,000 + $7,500 catch-up (50+). Total employee + employer: $69,000.

questions.question: After 2022, business meals at restaurants are generally deductible at what percentage?
questions.explanation: Business meals are generally 50% deductible (returned to normal after the temporary 100% deduction for 2021-2022). Entertainment expenses remain non-deductible.
questions.tip: Business meals: 50% deductible (post-2022). Entertainment: 0% deductible.

questions.question: For 2024, Social Security tax applies to wages up to:
questions.explanation: The 2024 Social Security wage base is $168,600. Wages above this amount are not subject to the 6.2% Social Security tax, but remain subject to the 1.45% Medicare tax (no cap).
questions.tip: 2024 SS wage base: $168,600. Medicare: No cap. Additional Medicare tax above $200K/$250K.

questions.question: A married couple selling their primary residence can exclude up to what amount of gain under Section 121?
questions.explanation: Married couples filing jointly can exclude up to $500,000 of gain on a primary residence ($250,000 for single filers). Requirements: owned and used as primary residence for 2 of prior 5 years.
questions.tip: Section 121: $500K MFJ, $250K single. 2-of-5-year ownership and use test.

questions.question: A married taxpayer gifts $50,000 to their child. With spouse's consent to split gifts, what is the taxable gift (after annual exclusions)?
questions.explanation: Gift-splitting treats the gift as $25,000 from each spouse. Annual exclusion per spouse per donee is $18,000 (2024). Taxable gift = ($25,000 - $18,000) × 2 = $14,000 total.
questions.tip: Gift-splitting: Halves the gift. Each spouse uses their own annual exclusion.

questions.question: A calendar-year corporation wants S corp status for 2024. By when must Form 2553 be filed?

options.B: March 15, 2024

questions.explanation: S elections must be filed by the 15th day of the 3rd month of the tax year (March 15 for calendar-year corporations). Late elections may qualify for relief under Rev. Proc. 2013-30.
questions.tip: S election: Due by 2 months, 15 days into the tax year. Late relief available.

questions.question: Partnership allocations that differ from ownership percentages must have:

options.B: Substantial economic effect

questions.explanation: Special allocations must have substantial economic effect under Section 704(b) to be respected. This requires economic effect (capital accounts, liquidation in accordance with capitals) and substantiality (meaningful economic impact beyond tax).
questions.tip: Special allocations: Must have substantial economic effect. Otherwise, reallocated per ownership.

questions.question: A taxpayer pays $6,000 in qualifying education expenses. What is the maximum American Opportunity Credit?
questions.explanation: AOC = 100% of first $2,000 + 25% of next $2,000 = $2,000 + $500 = $2,500 maximum. Additional expenses don't increase the credit. 40% ($1,000) is refundable.
questions.tip: AOC: $2,500 max (100% of $2K + 25% of next $2K). 40% refundable.

questions.question: A taxpayer with $100,000 AGI donates $70,000 cash to a public charity. What is the current year deduction?
questions.explanation: Cash donations to public charities are limited to 60% of AGI. Deduction = $100,000 × 60% = $60,000. The remaining $10,000 carries forward for up to 5 years.
questions.tip: Cash to public charity: 60% AGI limit. Excess carries forward 5 years.

questions.question: Many states enacted pass-through entity taxes (PTET) to work around which federal limitation?

options.B: $10,000 SALT deduction cap

questions.explanation: PTETs allow pass-through entities to pay state tax at the entity level, generating a federal business deduction. This bypasses the $10,000 individual SALT cap since the deduction is at the entity level.
questions.tip: PTET: State tax paid at entity level = federal business deduction. Workaround for $10K SALT cap.

questions.question: For dividends to qualify for preferential capital gains rates, the stock must be held for more than:

options.B: 60 days during the 121-day period around ex-dividend date

questions.explanation: Qualified dividends require holding the stock for more than 60 days during the 121-day period beginning 60 days before the ex-dividend date. Preferred stock has a 90-day/181-day requirement.
questions.tip: Qualified dividend holding: >60 days in 121-day window around ex-dividend date.

questions.question: When is income recognized on a nonqualified stock option (NSO)?

options.B: Vesting date

questions.explanation: NSOs trigger ordinary income at exercise equal to the bargain element (FMV minus exercise price). This differs from ISOs, which defer taxation until sale (if holding periods are met).
questions.tip: NSO: Ordinary income at exercise. ISO: No income at exercise (if holding periods met).

questions.question: A simple trust is required to:

options.B: Distribute all income currently and make no charitable contributions from corpus

questions.explanation: Simple trusts must distribute all income currently (no accumulation), cannot make charitable contributions from corpus, and cannot distribute corpus. All other trusts are complex trusts.
questions.tip: Simple trust: All income distributed currently, no charitable gifts from corpus, no corpus distributions.

questions.question: Stock becomes worthless in 2024. When is the loss deductible and what is the holding period determination?

options.A: 2024; holding period ends on actual worthlessness date
options.B: 2024; treated as sold on last day of the tax year
options.D: When the stock is formally cancelled

questions.explanation: Worthless securities are treated as sold for zero on the last day of the tax year in which they become worthless. This affects holding period—stock could become long-term by year-end even if it became worthless mid-year.
questions.tip: Worthless securities: Deemed sold December 31 of worthless year. May affect ST/LT character.

questions.question: Which type of income is generally included in personal holding company income?

options.B: Dividends, interest, and royalties

questions.explanation: PHC income includes passive investment income: dividends, interest, royalties, and certain rents. If PHC income exceeds 60% of adjusted ordinary gross income and 5 or fewer individuals own 50%+ stock, the 20% PHC tax applies.
questions.tip: PHC income: Passive investment types (dividends, interest, royalties, certain rents).

questions.question: A taxpayer converts $100,000 from a traditional IRA (all pre-tax) to a Roth IRA. What is the tax consequence?

options.A: No current tax; tax-free at distribution
options.B: $100,000 included in ordinary income; future qualified distributions tax-free

questions.explanation: Roth conversions include the converted amount in ordinary income (no 10% penalty for conversion itself). Future qualified distributions from the Roth are tax-free. The 5-year clock starts on conversion.
questions.tip: Roth conversion: Ordinary income now, tax-free later. No 10% penalty on conversion itself.

questions.question: A taxpayer with prior year AGI of $180,000 wants to avoid underpayment penalties. What percentage of current year tax must be paid through withholding and estimates?

options.B: 100% of prior year
options.C: 110% of prior year or 90% of current year

questions.explanation: For taxpayers with prior year AGI exceeding $150,000 MFJ ($75K MFS), the safe harbor is 110% of prior year tax (or 90% of current year). Below $150K, 100% of prior year tax satisfies the safe harbor.
questions.tip: High-income safe harbor (>$150K AGI): 110% of prior year tax OR 90% of current year tax.

questions.question: Can a non-working spouse's hours be counted toward a taxpayer's real estate professional status?

options.B: No—each spouse must independently qualify
options.C: Only for the 750-hour test, not the 50% test

questions.explanation: Each spouse must independently meet the REP tests. One spouse's hours cannot be combined with the other's for the >750 hour or >50% tests. However, either spouse qualifying allows joint return rental losses to be non-passive.
questions.tip: REP: Each spouse qualifies independently. One qualifying spouse benefits joint return.

questions.question: When is the FBAR (FinCEN 114) due for calendar year taxpayers?

options.B: April 15 with automatic extension to October 15

questions.explanation: FBAR is due April 15 with an automatic extension to October 15 (no request needed). This aligns with the tax return extended deadline. FBAR is filed electronically through FinCEN, not with the IRS.
questions.tip: FBAR: April 15, auto-extended to October 15. Filed with FinCEN, not IRS.

questions.question: A decedent leaves $20 million to their U.S. citizen spouse. What is the estate tax marital deduction?

options.B: $13.61 million

questions.explanation: The marital deduction is unlimited for property passing to a U.S. citizen spouse in a qualifying manner. The entire $20 million qualifies, resulting in no estate tax on the first death.
questions.tip: Marital deduction: Unlimited to U.S. citizen spouse. Non-citizen spouse requires QDOT.

questions.question: What is the maximum Section 179 deduction for 2024?
questions.explanation: The 2024 Section 179 limit is $1,160,000, with a phase-out beginning at $2,890,000 of property placed in service. The deduction is limited to taxable income from active business.
questions.tip: 2024 Section 179: $1,160,000 max. Phases out dollar-for-dollar over $2,890,000.

questions.question: Under Section 162(m), what is the maximum deductible compensation for covered employees of a publicly traded company?
questions.explanation: Section 162(m) limits the deduction for compensation paid to covered employees (CEO, CFO, and three highest-paid officers) to $1 million per person. Performance-based compensation exception was eliminated by TCJA.
questions.tip: Section 162(m): $1M deduction cap per covered employee. No performance-based exception anymore.

questions.question: The premium tax credit is available to taxpayers who:

options.B: Purchase coverage through a Marketplace exchange and meet income requirements

questions.explanation: The premium tax credit is available for coverage purchased through a Health Insurance Marketplace (exchange) by taxpayers with household income between 100-400% of FPL (no upper limit through 2025 under IRA extension).
questions.tip: PTC: Marketplace coverage required. Income limits currently extended through 2025.

questions.question: A business property is destroyed by fire. Insurance proceeds exceed basis. To defer gain under Section 1033, replacement property must be acquired within:

options.B: 2 years after the close of the first tax year in which gain is realized

questions.explanation: Section 1033 requires replacement within 2 years after the close of the first tax year in which gain is realized (3 years for condemned real property). Replacement property must be similar or related in service or use.
questions.tip: Section 1033: Replace within 2 years of year-end of gain realization (3 years for condemned realty).

questions.question: A partner contributes property and receives a distribution within 2 years. Under what circumstances is this treated as a disguised sale?

options.A: Never—contributions and distributions are always separate
options.B: If the distribution is fact-dependent on the contribution and not a reasonable return on capital
options.C: Only if formally documented as a sale
options.D: Always—any distribution within 2 years is a sale

questions.explanation: Section 707 disguised sale rules examine whether transfers within 2 years are interdependent. Distributions within 2 years are presumed related to contributions, but can be rebutted. Entrepreneurial risk and debt-financed distributions have safe harbors.
questions.tip: Disguised sale: Contribution + distribution within 2 years presumed sale. Facts and circumstances analysis.

questions.question: A grandparent makes a $15 million taxable transfer to a grandchild. What is the GST tax rate?

options.A: Equal to the highest estate tax rate (40%)

questions.explanation: The GST tax rate is a flat rate equal to the highest estate/gift tax rate (currently 40%). The $13.61 million GST exemption (2024) can shield transfers; amounts above are taxed at 40% in addition to any gift or estate tax.
questions.tip: GST tax: Flat 40% (highest estate rate). Separate $13.61M exemption from estate exemption.

questions.question: A C corporation has taxable income of $500,000. Federal taxes paid were $105,000 and it received $50,000 of tax-exempt bond interest. What is current E&P?
questions.explanation: E&P starts with taxable income and adjusts for economic reality. Add back tax-exempt income ($50,000), subtract federal taxes paid ($105,000). E&P = $500,000 + $50,000 - $105,000 = $445,000.
questions.tip: E&P: Taxable income + tax-exempt income - federal taxes - other adjustments.

questions.question: Assets in a rabbi trust established for deferred compensation are:

options.A: Taxable to the employee when contributed
options.B: Subject to claims of the employer's general creditors

questions.explanation: Rabbi trusts provide security against employer change-of-heart but remain subject to general creditors in bankruptcy. This maintains the tax deferral (not currently taxable) while providing some security. Secular trusts protect from creditors but trigger current taxation.
questions.tip: Rabbi trust: Subject to employer creditors = tax deferral. Creditor protection = current taxation.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns two businesses: one with $200,000 QBI and $50,000 W-2 wages, another with $100,000 QBI and $100,000 W-2 wages. Taxable income is $500,000. What is the benefit of aggregating?

options.A: Higher W-2 wages available for the combined limitation
options.B: Lower taxable income threshold

questions.explanation: Aggregation allows combining W-2 wages and qualified property across businesses. Without aggregation, business 1 is limited by its low W-2 wages. Aggregated, total QBI is $300,000 with $150,000 combined wages, allowing higher deduction.
questions.tip: 199A aggregation: Combines W-2 wages and property for limitation calculation. Often beneficial.

questions.question: Which of the following is Subpart F income that must be included by a U.S. shareholder of a CFC?

options.A: Manufacturing income from the CFC's country
options.B: Foreign base company sales income from related party transactions

questions.explanation: Foreign base company sales income (buying from or selling to related parties where goods are manufactured and sold outside the CFC's country) is Subpart F income. Active local manufacturing and local sales are generally not Subpart F.
questions.tip: Subpart F: Passive income + base company income (sales, services to related parties).

questions.question: A single taxpayer has $400,000 of business losses and $100,000 of business income. Under Section 461(l), how much business loss is currently deductible?
questions.explanation: Section 461(l) limits excess business losses to $305,000 (single, 2024) plus business income. Net business loss allowed = $100,000 + $305,000 = $405,000, which exceeds the $300,000 net loss. Full $300,000 net loss is allowed. Actually: threshold is $305K, net business loss = $300K, which is under threshold, so full loss allowed.
questions.tip: Excess business loss: Limited to ~$305K (single) / ~$610K (MFJ) plus business income.

questions.question: An intentionally defective grantor trust (IDGT) is 'defective' because:

options.A: It doesn't qualify for income tax benefits
options.B: It is ignored for income tax but recognized for estate/gift tax
options.C: It fails to meet trust requirements
options.D: It is included in the grantor's estate

questions.explanation: IDGTs are 'defective' for income tax (grantor taxed on trust income) but 'effective' for estate/gift tax (assets removed from estate). This allows sales to the trust without gain recognition while removing appreciation from the estate.
questions.tip: IDGT: Income tax = grantor's. Estate/gift = trust's. Intentional mismatch for planning.

questions.question: For Section 351 nonrecognition treatment, transferors must have 'control' immediately after the exchange. Control requires ownership of:

options.B: At least 80% of voting stock and 80% of all other classes
options.C: Any amount of stock if there's a business purpose

questions.explanation: Section 351 requires transferors (as a group) to control the corporation immediately after the exchange. Control means at least 80% of voting power and 80% of shares of each other class of stock.
questions.tip: Section 351 control: 80% voting + 80% of each class. Group can aggregate to meet threshold.
